head.title: July 16-22; A Slippery Particle Is Found

hedline.hl1: July 16-22; A Slippery Particle Is Found

block.p: An elusive particle that had been on physicists' Most Wanted list for 25 years has finally been detected, scientists announced at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. Called the tau neutrino, it is the last of a notoriously slippery family of particles to be seen. Those particles, all neutrinos of various kinds, pass through other matter almost without a trace. But they are crucial elements of the theory that particle physicists believe explains the structure of all matter.

An elusive particle that had been on physicists' Most Wanted list for 25 years has finally been detected, scientists announced at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. Called the tau neutrino, it is the last of a notoriously slippery family of particles to be seen. Those particles, all neutrinos of various kinds, pass through other matter almost without a trace. But they are crucial elements of the theory that particle physicists believe explains the structure of all matter.
Now there is just one more particle predicted by the theory that has not been seen. Physicists plan to begin chasing that particle, the Higgs boson, next spring.
